Custom Inverse Function

Inverse.Rd

Computes the multiplicative inverse of a Galois Field element. If the input is zero, it returns a representation of infinity in the projective space. For elements in the projective space, it returns zero.

Inverse(x)

Arguments

x

An object of class `GFElem` or `PGInf`. If `x` is an instance of `GFElem`, it should represent an element of a finite Galois Field. If `x` is an instance of `PGInf`, it represents the point at infinity in the projective space.

Value

An object of class `GFElem` if `x` is a Galois Field element and its inverse exists; otherwise, an object of class `PGInf` if `x` is zero. For projective space elements, returns zero.

Details

  • If `x` is a `GFElem` (Galois Field element) and is zero, the function returns a `PGInf` object, representing the point at infinity.

  • If `x` is a non-zero `GFElem`, the function calculates its inverse using the Extended Euclidean Algorithm (implemented in `GCDEEA`). The inverse is returned as a `GFElem` object.

  • If `x` is an instance of `PGInf` (point at infinity), the function returns a zero element in the Galois Field.

  • If `x` is neither a `GFElem` nor a `PGInf`, the function stops with an error.

Examples

# Find the inverse of a Galois Field element
elem <- GFElem$new(3, 7)
result <- Inverse(elem)
result$show()
#> GFElem{7}(5)

# Find the inverse of zero (should return the point at infinity)
zero_elem <- GFElem$new(0, 7)
result <- Inverse(zero_elem)
result$show()
#> PGInf{7}()

# Find the inverse of the point at infinity (should return zero)
infinity_point <- PGInf$new(7)
result <- Inverse(infinity_point)
result$show()
#> GFElem{7}(0)
